Boston and the rest of Massachusetts paused for a moment of quiet tribute and reflection exactly one week after the Marathon bombings. David L. Ryan/Globe Staff
Boston Mayor Thomas Menino, seated, US Attorney Carmen Ortiz, to Menino's right, and FBI Special Agent Richard DesLauriers, right, participated at a ceremony at the blast site on Monday. Robert F. Bukaty/AP
Nathalia Deleon (left) joined other fourth graders at the Blackstone Elementary School in Boston for a moment of silence to remember the Marathon bombing victims. Wendy Maeda/Globe Staff
The casket containing the body of bomb victim Krystle Campbell arrived at St. Joseph Church for her funeral Mass in Medford on Monday. Brian Snyder/Reuters
Firefighter Tim Freda from the Boylston Street Firehouse, Engine 33 Ladder 15 — amoung first responders to the bombings — painted signs in honor of the victims. Bill Greene/Globe Staff
Kevin Krueger of the North End paid his respect on Monday to the memorial on the Massachusetts Avenue end of Boylston Street. Bill Greene/Globe Staff
Waltham police closed off a street in 2011, the day after three men were found dead in an apartment. Authorities believe Tamerlan Tsarnaev may have played a role in the deaths. Joanne Rathe/Globe Staff/File
Dorchester residents stopped in Peabody Square to observe a moment of silence for the victims of the Boston Marathon bombing on Monday. Kayana Szymczak for The Boston Globe
Jack Fleming, of the Boston Athletic Association, which runs the Boston Marathon, paused at the finish line on Boylston Street on Monday. Robert F. Bukaty/AP
Hopkinton Town Hall employees stood silently, just down the street from the Marathon's starting line. Michele McDonald for the Boston Globe
At the end, Governor Deval Patrick thanked the crowd and said, “God bless the people of Massachusetts. Boston strong.” Justin Lane/EPA
People linked hands to form a human chain at a makeshift memorial for fallen MIT police officer Sean Collier. Steven Senne/AP
In Watertown, investigators continued to gather evidence from the bullet-ridden boat where the surviving suspect was found hiding on Friday. David L. Ryan/Globe Staff

Hundreds of Back Bay businesses remained closed because of the closed-off crime scene and struggle to assess damages and prepare insurance claims without seeing what shape their properties are in.

Series of Hyannis fires called arson

Investigators believe the fires that broke out at four Hyannis homes over the weekend were set intentionally, a fire official said on Monday. No one was injured.

Health & Wellness

Mediterranean diet vs. low-fat Ornish plan: Which is better?

The debate seemed to be settled with a study showing that the Mediterranean diet led to 30 percent fewer heart disease deaths, strokes, heart attacks than a low-fat diet in people over age 55 who hadn’t developed heart disease.
